Discharge Summary: Acute and Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis   The patient presented to the hospital with symptoms of an acute illness, which was later diagnosed as Acute and Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis. The patient had a history of Bicuspid Aortic Valve Disease and had previously undergone an aortic valve replacement surgery.   The patient was treated with a combination of antibiotics for six weeks, which successfully addressed the bacterial infection. A completed vegetation was found in the aortic valve, and multiple vegetations were found in the mitral valve. The patient had been diagnosed with bacteremia, for which they were also given medication.   The causative agent detected from the blood culture was MSSA (Methicillin-Sensitive Staphylococcus Aureus) and Streptococcus Bovis, which may have played a significant role in the patient's illness.   The medical team closely monitored the patient throughout their stay, ensuring that their blood counts remained stable, and that the medication did not result in any adverse reactions.   The patient was prescribed Metoprolol, a drug used to manage blood pressure and heart rate, and they were advised to continue using this medication.   The medical team also noted that the patient's illness may have been caused by a particle from the previously replaced valve, although this could not be confirmed.   The patient was discharged in a stable condition with appropriate education and instructions to manage their health. Follow-up consultations were scheduled with their physician.   In conclusion, the diagnosis of Acute and Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis is a severe illness that can result in significant morbidity and mortality. Patients with a history of valve replacement surgery should be monitored more closely, and it is essential to seek medical attention promptly if there are any signs or symptoms of infection.

Summary: The patient was diagnosed with acute and subacute bacterial endocarditis caused by a Streptococcus bovis bacteremia. The endocarditis had completed vegetation, with a large number of vegetations on the bicuspid and aortic valves. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics and metoprolol, which successfully controlled the infection and managed the patient's blood pressure. The patient responded well to the treatment, and the vegetations were eliminated. Follow-up echocardiography showed no residual particles or bacterial colonization. The patient was discharged after a 14-day hospitalization.

Patient: [Insert name]  Diagnosis: Acute and subacute bacterial endocarditis  On initial presentation, the patient presented with symptoms of fever, fatigue, malaise, and joint pain. Blood cultures were drawn and confirmed the presence of bacteremia. Further evaluation with transesophageal echocardiography revealed the presence of multiple vegetations on the bicuspid aortic valve.  The patient was diagnosed with acute and subacute bacterial endocarditis. Empiric antibiotic therapy was started with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. Blood cultures eventually grew Streptococcus bovis and methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). The patient was switched to ceftriaxone and rifampin to target the bovis and MSSA, respectively.  Infectious disease consult was obtained, and long-term therapy with ceftriaxone was recommended for 6 weeks. The patient's fever and fatigue gradually improved over the course of the hospitalization. Repeat transesophageal echocardiography after completion of antibiotic therapy revealed that the endocarditis had completed resolved and there were no longer any vegetations present.  The patient was discharged on metoprolol for management of hypertension and advised to follow-up with cardiology for continued monitoring of their valves. The patient was also instructed to complete a full course of antibiotic therapy as an outpatient.  Overall, this was a severe illness with a large number of vegetations present, but prompt diagnosis and appropriate management with antibiotics led to a favorable outcome and resolution of the infection.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was diagnosed with acute and subacute bacterial endocarditis caused by Streptococcus bovis. They completed a course of antibiotics and are currently stable. Vegetations were found on the patient's bicuspid aortic valve, which required surgical intervention. Bacteremia was also noted, which further intensified the illness. The patient was put on metoprolol to manage their symptoms.  The team was able to successfully treat the patient's endocarditis, and no new vegetations were observed during their stay. The number of particles in the patient's blood also decreased significantly. Treatment for MSSA bacteremia was provided, and the patient responded well to the medication.  At discharge, the patient was instructed to continue taking antibiotics and to schedule follow-up appointments with their cardiologist. They were advised to monitor their health closely and report any symptoms or concerns to their healthcare provider.

Name: [Patient's name] Age: [Patient's age] Diagnosis: Acute and subacute bacterial endocarditis  Patient presented with symptoms of sudden onset fever, chills, and fatigue. Blood cultures were positive for bacteremia, and an echocardiogram revealed a number of vegetations on the bicuspid aortic valve. The patient was diagnosed with Acute and subacute bacterial endocarditis.  Further testing confirmed that the causative agent was Streptococcus bovis. The patient completed a course of intravenous antibiotics targeting the bacteremia and was started on long-term oral antibiotics to treat the endocarditis.  Follow-up echocardiogram revealed that the vegetations had resolved, and the patient's illness showed significant improvement. The patient was discharged from the hospital with a prescription for metoprolol to manage arrhythmias related to the illness.  The patient was advised to continue taking the oral antibiotics as prescribed and to closely monitor any changes in their health or symptoms. Overall, this patient had a successful recovery from their bacterial endocarditis with appropriate management and treatment.
